mesmerize.sentence_1: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

inundate.sentence_1: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.

variance.meaning_1: noun: the quality of being different
variance.sentence_1: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to lie”.

underwrite.sentence_1: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

reprobate.meaning_1: noun: a person without morals who is disapproved of
reprobate.sentence_1: Mr. Smith’s two boys couldn’t be more different; one was a hard-working and principled, the other was the town reprobate, always having run-ins with the law.

insolvent.meaning_1: adjective: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt
insolvent.sentence_1: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.

voracious.meaning_1: adjective: very hungry; approaching an activity with gusto
voracious.sentence_1: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.

demure.meaning_1: adjective: to be modest and shy
demure.sentence_1: The portrait of her in a simple white blouse was sweet and demure.

miser.meaning_1: noun: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because they are greedy)
miser.sentence_1: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

amiable.sentence_1: Amy’s name was very apt: she was so amiable that she was twice voted class president.

indict.meaning_1: verb: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing
indict.sentence_1: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.

macabre.meaning_1: adjective: suggesting the horror of death and decay; gruesome
macabre.sentence_1: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of the macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to—and often those moments after—a grisly death.

retiring.meaning_1: adjective: to be shy, and to be inclined to retract from company
retiring.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
retiring.sentence_1: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees—rather than mill about with “fashionable” folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.

hound.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
hound.sentence_1: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms—he even helped nab Al Capone.

unnerve.meaning_1: verb: to make nervous or upset
unnerve.sentence_1: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly “Magoosh-ing”, and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.

spendthrift.meaning_1: noun: one who spends money extravagantly
spendthrift.sentence_1: Taking weekly trips to Vegas, Megan was a spendthrift whose excesses eventually caught up to her.

thrifty.sentence_1: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

pinnacle.sentence_1: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

affable.meaning_1: adjective: likeable; easy to talk to
affable.sentence_1: For all his surface affability, Marco was remarkably glum when he wasn’t around other people.

vindictive.meaning_1: adjective: to have a very strong desire for revenge
vindictive.sentence_1: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.

dupe.sentence_2: The charlatan mistook the crowd for a bunch of dupes, but the crowd was quickly on to him and decried his bald-faced attempt to bilk them.
dupe.meaning_2: noun: a person who is easily tricked or swindled
dupe.sentence_1: Once again a get-rich-fast Internet scheme had duped Harold into submitting a $5,000 check to a sham operation.

candid.sentence_1: Even with a perfect stranger, Charles was always candid and would rarely hold anything back.

affluent.sentence_1: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.

pine.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
pine.sentence_1: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.

zenith.sentence_1: At the zenith of his artistic career, Elvis was outselling any other artist on the charts.

demean.meaning_1: verb: to insult; to cause someone to lose dignity or respect
demean.sentence_1: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.

telling.meaning_1: adjective: significant and revealing of another factor
telling.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
telling.sentence_1: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.

erratic.sentence_1: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President’s attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.

err.sentence_1: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

screed.sentence_1: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government’s deficiencies--only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big business.

bleak.meaning_1: adjective: having a depressing or gloomy outlook
bleak.sentence_1: Unremitting overcast skies tend to lead people to create bleak literature and lugubrious music — compare England’s band Radiohead to any band from Southern California.

indignant.meaning_1: adjective: feeling anger over a perceived injustice
indignant.sentence_1: When the cyclist swerved into traffic, it forced the driver to brake and elicited an indignant shout of "Hey, punk, watch where you're going!"

summit.sentence_2: Since climate change policy has been mired in congressional fighting, this summit should help set the goals for president's next term.
summit.meaning_2: noun: a meeting of high-level leaders
summit.sentence_1: After hiking for seven days, the climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro.
summit.meaning_1: noun: the peak or highest point

censor.sentence_2: The censor insisted that every reference to drugs should be removed from the manuscript.
censor.meaning_2: noun: an official who censors material
censor.sentence_1: Every fall, high school English teachers are inundated by requests to censor their curriculum by removing The Catcher in the Rye and Scarlet Letter from their reading lists.
censor.meaning_1: verb: to examine and remove objectionable material

slapdash.meaning_1: adjective: carelessly and hastily put together
slapdash.sentence_1: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the façade of the building.

dog.meaning_1: verb: to pursue relentlessly; to hound
dog.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
dog.sentence_1: Throughout his life, he was dogged by insecurities that inhibited personal growth.

tender.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
tender.sentence_1: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.

thoroughgoing.sentence_1: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.

acme.meaning_1: noun: the highest point of achievement
acme.sentence_1: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.

telltale.sentence_1: The many telltale signs of chronic smoking include yellow teeth, and a persistent, hacking cough.

diabolical.meaning_1: adjective: to be extremely wicked like the devil
diabolical.sentence_1: The conspirators, willing to dispatch anyone who stood in their way, hatched a diabolical plan to take over the city.

stipend.sentence_1: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

inflammatory.sentence_1: It only takes one person to leave an inflammatory comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.

remiss.meaning_1: adjective: to be negligent in one’s duty
remiss.sentence_1: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principal was relieved of his position after only three months.

embroiled.meaning_1: verb: involved in argument or contention
embroiled.sentence_1: These days we are never short of a D.C. politician embroiled in scandal—a welcome phenomenon for those who, having barely finished feasting on the sordid details of one imbroglio, can sink their teeth into a fresh one.

peruse.sentence_1: Instead of perusing important documents, people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures at the bottom.

profuse.meaning_1: adjective: plentiful; pouring out in abundance
profuse.sentence_1: During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

tirade.sentence_1: In terms of political change, a tirade oftentimes does little more than make the person speaking red in the face.

serendipity.meaning_1: noun: the instance in which an accidental, fortunate discovery is made
serendipity.sentence_1: By pure serendipity, Sarah discovered, at a flea market in Peoria, a matching earring to replace the one that fell down the storm drain back home.

indigenous.meaning_1: adjective: originating in a certain area
indigenous.sentence_1: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S—one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you’re not dealing with an opossum.
